author: holgerd77
content:
Just wondering since I was questioned about this on Discord and we already stumbled upon this opcode a couple of times when doing stuff in a more stateless way: what is the future of the `BLOCKHASH` opcode in a stateless (verkle) world? ü§î

Has this been already discussed or written down somewhere (happy to pointers, no need to rewrite all the stuff here)?

So the opocode provides a number -> hash mapping for the last 256 blocks, correct me if I am wrong.

Has it been discussed (e.g. in a verkle context, but generally if things go "more stateless") to deprecate this opcode at some point? Or will requested number -> hash block mappings be included in the witness for a block?

author: sky.cactus
content: The two plans I have seen are to include the needed mappings in the witness, or move the mapping into the state trie (so `BLOCKHASH` opcode is basically just an `SLOAD` of sorts).

author: sky.cactus
content: I highly doubt removing `BLOCKHASH` opcode would be accepted as that would break a number of contracts.

author: bridge-bot
content:

Has this been already discussed or written down somewhere (happy to pointers, no need to rewrite all the stuff here)?

So the opocode provides a number -> hash mapping for the last 256 blocks, correct me if I am wrong.

Has it been discussed (e.g. in a verkle context, but generally if things go "more stateless") to deprecate this opcode at some point? Or will requested number -> hash block mappings be included in the witness for a block?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <asqyzeron> but for applications that are currently available, as long as you statelessly execute all blocks, you can save the block hash of each block

author: holgerd77
content:
I see. For a stateless execution of blocks that would mean though that a client would always need to wait for 256 blocks to pass until a safe all-contract execution becomes possible. Which is likely not the final state of what we want.

Thanks for putting it on the call agenda!
